item.title: 'I did nothing wrong': Ashton stands firm amid Informer 3838 scandal - The Age
item.description:
1. 'I did nothing wrong': Ashton stands firm amid Informer 3838 scandal  The Age
  2. Embarrassing affair details emerge in latest Lawyer X revelations  3AW
  3. Victoria Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton responds to Lawyer X scandal  ABC News
  4. State’s worst drug dealers may get compensation due to Informer 3838 scandal  The Age

  6. View full coverage on Google News

item.title: Senior Victoria Police officers turned 'blind eye' to use of gangland lawyer as informant says Ron Iddles - ABC News
item.description:
Senior Victoria Police officers turned 'blind eye' to use of gangland lawyer as informant says Ron Iddles  ABC News

Former homicide squad detective Ron Iddles says up to 15 senior police officers turned a blind eye to the consequences of using a criminal barrister as an ...

item.title: Ashton oversaw corruption investigations using Informer 3838 - The Age
item.description:
Ashton oversaw corruption investigations using Informer 3838  The Age

Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton was part of a high-ranking law enforcement group responsible for overseeing potentially tainted investigations.

item.description:
Ashton to stay top cop as Lawyer X inquiry proceeds  ABC Local

The chief commissioner of Victoria Police, Graham Ashton, says he's not planning to step down from his role as the state's top cop, despite the fact he'll be called ...

Interstate hunt for royal commissioners  The Macleay Argus

A royal commission into revelations a turncoat lawyer helped convict scores of crooks she was meant to be representing is likely to be led by interstate ...

item.description:
Premier and police commissioner knew Bourke St attacker was on bail  The Age

Premier Daniel Andrews and Police Commissioner Graham Ashton knew that Bourke Street terrorist Hassan Khalif Shire Ali was on bail the day after the deadly ...

item.title: OPP considering decision on rorts-for-votes scandal - Herald Sun
item.description:
OPP considering decision on rorts-for-votes scandal  Herald Sun

The Office of Public Prosecutions is now considering whether charges should be laid over the rorts-for-votes scandal.

item.title: Graham Ashton speaks to ABC Radio Melbourne's Jon Faine - ABC News
item.description:
Graham Ashton speaks to ABC Radio Melbourne's Jon Faine  ABC News

Victoria Police Commissioner Graham Ashton said he expects he will be called to testify at a royal commission into Informer 3838.

item.title: Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton - ABC News
item.description:
Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton  ABC News

Victoria Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said police will cooperate with a royal commission into the force's use of a criminal defence lawyer as an ...

item.title: Police treating Bourke Street attack as terrorism - ABC News
item.description:
Police treating Bourke Street attack as terrorism  ABC News

Victoria Police chief commissioner Graham Ashton says one person has died and two others are injured after a man drove his car down Melbourne's Bourke ...

item.title: Lawyer X tale of twisted justice - The Australian
item.description:
Lawyer X tale of twisted justice  The Australian

To look at him, you’d never know he was a killer. A neat, bespectacled, soft-spoken man, he had none of the bogan bravado that coursed through Melbourne’s gangland. That’s what made him so scary. As defence lawyer Zarah Garde-Wilson tells Inquirer: “If he knocked on your door to say he was there to fix your Foxtel, you would let him in in a split second.” Don’t be fooled. Even within the bloodthirsty context of the gangland war, “Cable Guy” was a particularly nasty piece of work. He was involved in the executions of three people, all carried out in full view of children: Jason Moran and Pas...

item.title: Gangsters, cops and Lawyer X: the police informant scandal that has shocked Australia - The Guardian
item.description:
Gangsters, cops and Lawyer X: the police informant scandal that has shocked Australia  The Guardian

In 2005, eight years after the murder of the underworld figure Alphonse Gangitano kicked off a long and bloody gangland war on the streets of Melbourne, a prominent criminal barrister agreed to become a registered police informant in exchange for a promise that her identity would be kept secret. The woman – known variously as Lawyer X, EF, and informer 3838 – had represented some of the gangland war’s most infamous figures, including Carl Williams and Tony Mokbel. If EF exposes herself to risk by not entering the witness protection program, she will be bound by the consequences High court r...

item.title: Roberta Williams: Lawyer X told Carl to flee overseas - The Advertiser
item.description:
Roberta Williams: Lawyer X told Carl to flee overseas  The Advertiser

She says that in 2004, after a meeting with Lawyer X, Williams told her the lawyer had “said that I should f--- off overseas”. He then said: “I’m going to get pinched. What should I stay here for?” But Roberta Williams, who says she had then been unaware of the extent of his criminality, talked him out of absconding. PT 1: HOW LAWYER X SHAPED MELBOURNE’S GANGLAND WAR FAT TONY’S BIG BASH: LAST DRINKS BEFORE ARRESTS TONY MOKBEL: I WAS URGED TO FLEE Williams was ultimately bashed to death with an exercise bike stem in Barwon jail, where he was serving a 35-year sentence for four murders. The H...

item.title: Victoria announces royal commission into potentially tainted gangland convictions - ABC News
item.description:
Victoria announces royal commission into potentially tainted gangland convictions  ABC News

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has announced a royal commission into a number of gangland convictions which could be appealed due to the use by police of a criminal defence lawyer as an informant. The informant was a criminal defence barrister for several people who were convicted of criminal offences over the past two decades. At the same time, the barrister acted as an informant to Victoria Police about some of these people. The announcement of a royal commission followed the lifting of suppression orders this morning on a case decided in the High Court last month involving Victoria Pol...

item.title: Going Down Under: Lawyer exposed as police informer puts 100s of convictions at risk - RT
item.description:
Going Down Under: Lawyer exposed as police informer puts 100s of convictions at risk  RT

Hundreds of Australian criminals, including a gangland kingpin, could now walk free after it was revealed that their defense lawyer was leaking confidential information as a police informant. Court documents published online Monday show that the lawyer, referred to only as EF, operated as a police informant between 2005-2009 under the codename 3838. EF kept in daily touch with police handlers who then passed on the information to task forces. The shocking revelations follow a secret two-year high court battle that ended last month, where Victoria Police had attempted to block state prosecut...

item.title: Three men charged in Australia for allegedly plotting 'chilling' terror attacks in Melbourne - The Telegraph
item.description:
Three men charged in Australia for allegedly plotting 'chilling' terror attacks in Melbourne  The Telegraph

Three men who allegedly plotted "chilling" terror attacks in Melbourne were charged early Tuesday, less than two weeks after a stabbing rampage inspired by Isil left two dead in Australia's second city, police said. The trio, all Australian nationals of Turkish descent, were detained by counter-terror police in overnight raids as they escalated preparations to attack crowded areas of Melbourne, according to police. The three, two brothers aged 31 and 26 and 21-year-old, were later charged with planning a terrorist action, which carries a maximum penalty of life in prison, officials said. Vi...

item.title: Melbourne terror plot: Three arrested in Australia after 'ISIS-inspired' attack foiled - CNN
item.description:
Melbourne terror plot: Three arrested in Australia after 'ISIS-inspired' attack foiled  CNN

Police in Australia said they have foiled a terror plot "inspired by ISIS" in which assailants were planning to target a prominent public places in Melbourne, a city still reeling from a deadly attack two weeks ago. Victoria Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said Tuesday that three people had been arrested in connection with the plot. Their planned attack hadn't been finalized, but the men had been intending to target a prominent public place. "There was a view towards a crowded place, a place where maximum people would be attending to be able to kill, we allege, kill a maximum amount...

item.title: Melbourne terror trio planned mass shooting in crowded space: police - ABC News
item.description:
Melbourne terror trio planned mass shooting in crowded space: police  ABC News

Three men arrested on suspicion of plotting a terror attack in Melbourne had tried to source a semi-automatic rifle to kill as many people as possible in a crowded space, police will allege. The men, who are from the city's northern suburbs, had been under surveillance since March, police said. They said the men — brothers Ertunc and Samed Eriklioglu, aged 30 and 26, and 21-year-old Hanifi Halis — were inspired by the Islamic State (IS) terror group. The three men made a brief appearance in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court this afternoon, charged with preparing for an act of terrorism. The ...

item.title: Australia police arrest three men over terrorist attack plan - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Australia police arrest three men over terrorist attack plan  Al Jazeera English

Australian police arrested three men they say were preparing a terrorist attack in Melbourne, the country's second biggest city, less than two weeks after a man was killed in a rampage that police said was inspired by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant group (ISIL). Australian federal and state police, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and other agencies that form part of the country's Joint Counter Terrorism Team carried out the arrests on Tuesday morning. The three men - Australians of Turkish descent aged 30, 26 and 21 - will be charged with terrorism-related offenc...

item.title: Police investigate link between Bourke St 'trolley man' and burglaries - ABC News
item.description:
Police investigate link between Bourke St 'trolley man' and burglaries  ABC News

The "trolley man" who confronted the Bourke Street terrorist during the deadly Melbourne attack earlier this month is wanted for questioning by Victoria Police over a number of recent burglaries. He could be seen on video using the trolley to try to prevent Shire Ali from continuing his attack, which claimed the life of popular restaurateur Sisto Malaspina. Shire Ali stabbed three men — fatally wounding Mr Malaspina — before he was shot in the chest by police and later died in hospital. But police revealed on Thursday night they wanted to speak with the 46-year-old over a number of recent b...

item.title: Police ‘may split over Pell’ - The Australian
item.description:
Police ‘may split over Pell’  The Australian

It was not unusual for police to have different views, particularly in complex matters, chief commissioner Graham Ashton said this morning. Nevertheless, a decision was closer, he said. Mr Ashton also revealed that the Taskforce Sano would liaise with lawyers for Cardinal Pell and the victims if a decision was made not to charge the senior Vatican figure. Victoria police has had advice from the Office of Public Prosecutions for two weeks, however has not disclosed the details of that advice.

item.title: Australia police: Melbourne attack 'act of terrorism' - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Australia police: Melbourne attack 'act of terrorism'  Al Jazeera English

Australian police are treating a deadly siege in the southern city of Melbourne as an "act of terrorism" after a claim by ISIL that one of its fighters was the gunman responsible. Police shot dead Yacqub Khayre on Monday after he held a woman hostage inside an apartment building in Melbourne, Australia's second-largest city. Police confirmed on Tuesday that Khayre, who was acquitted of a plot to attack a Sydney army base in 2009, had shot a man dead in the foyer of the building. "This terrorist attack by a known criminal, a man who was only recently released on parole, is a shocking, coward...

item.title: In-flight terror — looks like we’re on our own - The Advertiser
item.description:
In-flight terror — looks like we’re on our own  The Advertiser

For one hour and 34 minutes last Wednesday night, frightened passengers were forced to wait on the Tullamarine tarmac, knowing that the man who allegedly had threatened to blow up the plane was hogtied on board, along with his suspected bomb and a full tank of fuel. And so far no one in authority has adequately explained why immediate evacuation, standard operating procedure around the world, did not occur. The passengers know the score. “Honestly, if it were a real terrorist we would have been toast,’’ said Dan Toner. “You see this huge ring of police and firefighters in this perimeter all...

item.title: ‘Risk-averse culture hampers cops’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘Risk-averse culture hampers cops’  The Australian

Bill Tilley, a former policeman, said a decade-long cultural change had hampered the efforts of frontline police. He said it was problematic that Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton had never worked on the frontline in the state force, and too many outsiders were being propelled into senior roles. “Over the past 10 years, we have seen a lot of people’s passports stamped for promotion and they tend to err on the side of caution … (they are) risk-averse, not wanting any undue attention brought to them, they want to see their final years out with a good solid superannuation,” Mr Tilley told The A...

item.title: Seven held over alleged Christmas Day 'act of evil' terror plot - ABC News
item.description:
Seven held over alleged Christmas Day 'act of evil' terror plot  ABC News

Seven people have been arrested in Melbourne after allegedly preparing for a terrorist plot, Victoria Police said. Key points: - Police believe plot involved use of explosives and other weapons and could have been planned for Christmas Day - High profile locations including Federation Square and Flinders Street Station were targeted, police say - Five people arrested still in custody and are being questioned by police The arrests came after properties at Flemington, Meadow Heights and Dallas in Melbourne were raided as part of a counter-terrorism operation involving Victoria Police, the Aus...

item.title: Decision on possible Pell charges likely in 'next few weeks' - ABC News
item.description:
Decision on possible Pell charges likely in 'next few weeks'  ABC News

The head of Victoria Police has indicated a decision is likely in the next few weeks on whether to charge Catholic Cardinal George Pell in relation to sexual abuse allegations dating back to the late 1970s. Key points: - A decision on possible charges would be made based on the evidence, the likelihood of conviction - The decision would probably be made fairly quickly, in a few weeks - Cardinal Pell repeated his denials restated his innocence, saying he would continue to co-operate fully Police confirmed on Wednesday they had received advice from Victoria's Director of Public Prosecutions [...

item.title: Bourke Street 'trolley man' out on bail after burglary charge, bail offences - ABC News
item.description:
Bourke Street 'trolley man' out on bail after burglary charge, bail offences  ABC News

The homeless man who confronted the Bourke Street terrorist with a trolley last week, prompting an online campaign to raise more than $140,000, has been released on bail after facing court over five theft-related offences. Michael Rogers, 46, is accused of stealing a bike from an apartment block in Melbourne in October and for breaking into a CBD cafe earlier this month and taking $500. The court heard Mr Rogers had faced homelessness and ongoing drug issues, and was released from a five-month stint behind bars in August. It also heard the money raised in the online campaign had been placed...

item.title: Police apology to abuse victims - The Australian
item.description:
Police apology to abuse victims  The Australian

The true number of such abuse victims will never be known as records were not kept, have since been lost or were destroyed. That such an apology is being considered at this level shows both its extent and the damage done are feared to be significant. More than half a million children are estimated to have spent time in an orphanage, home or foster care over the past century. They represent more than 40 per cent of the 6349 people who have given evidence in private to the child abuse royal commission to date saying they were abused. In a letter sent last week and seen by The Australian, Vict...

item.title: Three killed, including a child, after car mows down pedestrians in Melbourne - The Guardian
item.description:
Three killed, including a child, after car mows down pedestrians in Melbourne  The Guardian

Three people have been killed, including a young child, and at least 15 injured after a car drove into pedestrians in Bourke Street, one of the busiest areas in Melbourne’s central business district. Victoria police confirmed on Friday afternoon the victims were a young child and a man and a woman, both in their 30s. None of the dead were believed to be related. Victorian police commissioner Graham Ashton said the death toll could rise, as five of the injured were listed as critical, including a child whose pram could be seen lying on the road amid the carnage. The Royal Children’s hospital...

item.title: From triumph to tragedy - The Australian
item.description:
From triumph to tragedy  The Australian

After months of gruelling training, the fresh-faced 20-year-old officially became an Australian soldier as she took part in a march-out ceremony, thousands of kilometres from her Perth home watched by her mother, at the army’s training barracks in Kapooka, NSW. Just four months later — on Sunday, July 16 — she was found dead in the shower of a Melbourne hotel room that had been rented by a group of men on a buck’s night. Victoria Police have pieced ­together Private Rowley’s final hours at the Oaks on Market apartments through interviews with some of the men on the buck’s night, and have in...

item.title: Christmas terrorist plot foiled in Australia, ISIS-inspired suspects arrested - RT
item.description:
Christmas terrorist plot foiled in Australia, ISIS-inspired suspects arrested  RT

Australian authorities have foiled a “very substantial terrorist plot”, arresting a number of suspects who allegedly plotted a “multi-mode attack” involving guns and improvised explosives in central Melbourne over the Christmas holidays. Seven people were detained following overnight raids by Victoria Police, the Australian Federal Police and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) on Friday. Five people are still in custody and are answering questions about the alleged terrorist plot. Victoria Police would like to reassure the community that the threat has been contained. Deta...

item.title: Nightmare on Bourke Street - The Australian
item.description:
Nightmare on Bourke Street  The Australian

In the wake of the carnage that stunned the nation, doctors ­battled to try to save the life of a three-month-old baby who was among five critically injured when the 26-year-old driver ploughed his maroon Commodore at high speed into terrified shoppers, tourists and families. Police, who had earlier called off a pursuit of the car on safety grounds, rammed his vehicle and shot him. He was arrested and under guard in hospital last night. The man, identified by media outlets as Dimitrious Gargasoulas, was wanted for allegedly stabbing his brother earlier yesterday before­ taking a woman hosta...

item.title: ‘No crime in soldier’s death’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘No crime in soldier’s death’  The Australian

Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said the investigation into Private Rowley’s death was continuing. She was found dead on July 16, in the shower of a room in Melbourne’s Oaks on Market apartments that had been rented by a group of men on a bucks’ night. It later emerged she was a member of the Aus­tralian Army. Mr Ashton told Melbourne radio 3AW yesterday police investigators were awaiting the coroner’s final report on the cause of death. He agreed the case had ­initially looked suspicious. “On its surface when you look at those details — bucks’ party, hotel room — it does look like it,” he...

item.title: Pell ‘hanging in there’ - The Australian
item.description:
Pell ‘hanging in there’  The Australian

Cardinal Pell, looking less robus­t than when he fronted the specially convened Rome sitting of the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse last year, emerged from his Rome home overlooking the walls of the Vatican with another cardinal in tow. Cardinal Pell, 75, told The Australian he was innocent of the claims being made against him. “Let me just repeat, I am not guilty of any crime,’’ he said as a posse of special police surroun­d­ed his chauffeur-driven car. “I have co-operated fully and will co-operate fully and I await the decision.’’ When asked how he was ...

item.title: Terrorist may have lured police to deadly shootout in Australian suburbs - CNN
item.description:
Terrorist may have lured police to deadly shootout in Australian suburbs  CNN

A former terror suspect with a "long record of violence" took a sex worker hostage in a suburban Australian apartment building Monday, in what police say may have been an attempt to lure law enforcement to a gunfight. One man was killed, and three police officers injured, as a result of the hostage standoff in the Melbourne suburb of Brighton, which ended after the attacker -- since named as 29-year-old Yacub Khayre -- was shot dead by police. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull told reporters Tuesday the attack was being treated as a terrorist incident, saying it had "shocked all Au...

item.title: Melbourne CBD attack death toll rises to four - The Australian
item.description:
Melbourne CBD attack death toll rises to four  The Australian

• A man and woman aged in their 30s were killed in the incident. • Of the injured, five are critical, including one child. • The driver of the car, a 26-year-old, was shot in the arm and arrested after his car was rammed by police. • He is under guard Melbourne’s St Vincent’s Hospital. • Police say he known to them and has a history of drug, violence and mental health issues. • Police have asked people to stay away from the CBD, and hospitals are urging those with non-emergencies to see their local GP or local hospital. • The incident followed a stabbing, and was not terror-related. • The d...

item.title: Australia Detains 5 in IS-inspired Christmas Day Bomb Plot - VOA News
item.description:
Australia Detains 5 in IS-inspired Christmas Day Bomb Plot  VOA News

Several people allegedly planning a series of bomb attacks in Melbourne, Australia, on Christmas Day have been arrested, and the plot was foiled, police said Friday. "This is a significant disruption of what we would describe as an imminent terrorist event in Melbourne," Australian Federal Police Commissioner Andrew Colvin told reporters in Sydney. "We do believe ... that we have removed this threat in its entirety." Originally, seven people, all in their 20s, were arrested, police said. But two people — a man and a woman — were released later Friday. Five men are still being detained, poli...

item.title: Police targeting ‘fake’ beggars - The Australian
item.description:
Police targeting ‘fake’ beggars  The Australian

While the Andrews government yesterday acknowledged there was a “serious homeless problem” in Victoria, chief police commissioner Graham Ashton claimed people were often choosing to live on the streets “I think it looks disgusting what you see in the city,” Mr Ashton said, insisting there were ­adequate beds and accommo­dation for those in need. “There’s no reason that anyone should be sleeping on the street, there’s no reason that anyone should be homeless. “Quite often what happens is they don’t want to be in those ­assisted accommodation or that emergency accommodation, they choose to be...

item.title: How cops missed rampage driver - The Australian
item.description:
How cops missed rampage driver  The Australian

Police appear to have botched what may have been their best chance to stop Gargasoulas without risking civilian lives when they sent a helicopter to the quiet, suburban street in response to a triple-0 call. Two witnesses who spoke with Gargasoulas while he was parked told The Australian that as soon as the helicopter thundered into view Gargasoulas fled the scene. From there, he drove straight into the city where he allegedly killed five people and injured more than 30 in a murderous rampage. The details of Gargasoulas’s final stop in Drew Street, Yarraville can be revealed as Victoria Pol...

item.title: Competence, not gender - The Australian
item.description:
Competence, not gender  The Australian

The former chief commissioner of Victoria Police claimed Jeff Kennett had told her he would never appoint her to the most senior policing position in Victoria. Nixon claimed the former premier’s comments were driven by sexism. Kennett denied making the comments and said any issue he had with Nixon’s performance were related to her performance rather than her gender. Nixon has often played the gender card as a defence for her shortcomings. As VicPol’s first female chief commissioner, she was no stranger to controversy and this came to a head with her evidence to the 2009 Victorian Bushfire R...

item.title: Stairs too short in jet rescue - The Australian
item.description:
Stairs too short in jet rescue  The Australian

Amid mounting criticism over the handling of the Melbourne Airport incident last week, Victoria Police has confirmed stairs were requested early in the operation but wouldn’t say how long it took for them to arrive. “The door chosen … was the most rear door away from the (suspected) device, however, the operator of the stairs indicated that they would not reach that door height,” Victoria Police media officer Melissa Seach said. “It was subsequently redirected to the next door along. The time taken to redirect towards the newly chosen door took another 90 seconds at the most.” The revelatio...

item.title: Passenger tried to enter the cockpit on Malaysia Airlines flight - CNN
item.description:
Passenger tried to enter the cockpit on Malaysia Airlines flight  CNN

Australian police have defended their actions after a passenger tried to force his way into the cockpit on a Malaysia Airlines flight from Melbourne to Kuala Lumpur Thursday. Just after a takeoff, a male passenger on Flight MH128 tried to enter the cockpit while holding what one passenger described as a "huge, unusual, black, metallic, strange thing... size of a watermelon." "He was yelling 'I need to see the pilot, I need to see the pilot,'" passenger and former AFL player Andrew Leoncelli told Australia's ABC News. The mid-flight scare ended safely, but passengers later criticized the pol...

item.title: Family fracas preceded havoc - The Australian
item.description:
Family fracas preceded havoc  The Australian

The 26-year-old man, who ­allegedly led police on a lengthy car chase yesterday morning, “was not on our indices as having any relationship with terrorism,” Victoria Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said last night. The man was identified by the Herald Sun and radio station 3AW as Dimitri Gargasoulas. A YouTube video titled “Deathbox Burnouts”, apparently linked to the man, featured an older model sedan doing a lengthy­ series of doughnuts until a tire caught on fire. Speaking alongside Premier Daniel Andrews, Mr Ashton said the man had been charged with assault offences last weekend...

item.title: Mentally ill man who tried to hijack Malaysia Airlines plane told 'get back to your f***ing seat' by 'heroic' passengers - The Independent
item.description:
Mentally ill man who tried to hijack Malaysia Airlines plane told 'get back to your f***ing seat' by 'heroic' passengers  The Independent

A mentally ill man who tried to hijack a Malaysia Airlines plane was told to “get back to your f***ing seat” by other passengers. The plane was forced to return to Australia when a 25-year-old Sri Lankan man threatened to detonate a bomb and attempted to enter the cockpit before being tackled and tied up by passengers. The man, who has not been named, had been discharged from a Melbourne psychiatric hospital before buying a ticket on the late-night flight to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Victorian Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said. Read more - Somali pirates hijack small Indian boat wi...

item.title: CA’s response to Melbourne terror arrests - The Advertiser
item.description:
CA’s response to Melbourne terror arrests  The Advertiser

A “significant” Islamic State-inspired Christmas Day terror plot targeting central Melbourne with explosives was foiled after a series of arrests in raids across the city, police said Friday. “Our security team is in contact with the relevant authorities to ensure we have the appropriate level of security at the Boxing Day Test and other cricket matches being held around the country,” CA chief executive officer James Sutherland said after the news broke. “The safety and security of our fans, players and officials attending any cricket match is our number one priority. “We applaud Victoria P...

item.title: IS claims responsibility - The Australian
item.description:
IS claims responsibility  The Australian

Police gunned down the ­hostage-taker after he held a woman for at least two hours and another man’s body was found at the entrance to the apartments in bayside Brighton. Senior police sources confirmed last night that the incident was being treated as a terrorist ­attack unless proven otherwise. • Brighton hostage siege: live coverage continues here The Australian confirmed that the hostage-taker, whose body was riddled with bullet wounds, was known to counter-terrorism police but that investigators were open-minded about whether terrorism was the trigger for the shootout. The fact a count...

item.title: TAC was rash in cutting Cats deal - The Advertiser
item.description:
TAC was rash in cutting Cats deal  The Advertiser

The high profile Cats skipper was caught driving at 127kmh in 100kmh zone. On Tuesday, 11 days later, the TAC officially announced its decision in a press release: “In January 2015, the Cats stated publicly that in the event of any further serious incidents the partnership would be relinquished, and the TAC respects the club’s integrity.’’ Chief executive Brian Cook made the 2015 statement after Dawson Simpson, now at GWS, was caught drink-driving. Still, the sponsorship remained in place despite the drink-driving charge. Clearly, the TAC wasn’t backing down this time. It had every right no...

item.title: Police commissioners planning to apologise to child sex abuse victims - ABC News
item.description:
Police commissioners planning to apologise to child sex abuse victims  ABC News

Australia's police commissioners are considering issuing an apology to victims of child sex abuse following the release of a royal commission report later this year. Key points: - Victoria's police commissioner Graham Ashton says national apology likely to occur - Police chiefs to wait until release of royal commission findings before making decision - Victims ask "why do we need to wait?" The matter was considered at a meeting of Australia's police chiefs in September after a request from the Care Leavers Australasia Network (CLAN), which supports and advocates for people abused as childre...

item.title: Cops ‘didn’t have funds’ - The Australian
item.description:
Cops ‘didn’t have funds’  The Australian

In the wake of the Malmsbury youth justice centre riot last week and the Bourke Street attack, Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton yesterday defended Victoria Police against criticism it has become “soft on crime”, but said the organisation had been under-resourced before to December. “We haven’t had the equipment needed to get the job done, we haven’t had the right education ... to get the job done,” Mr Ashton said yesterday. “The investment we got from the government before Christmas is allowing us to do that, to ­embark on a significant modernisation so that we will be there, well equipped,...

item.title: ISIS claims responsibility for Melbourne shooting & hostage situation - RT
item.description:
ISIS claims responsibility for Melbourne shooting & hostage situation  RT

Australian police are treating a shooting and hostage situation in Melbourne that left two men dead, including the attacker, as an “act of terrorism”. It comes after Islamic State reportedly claimed responsibility for the drama. “We are treating it as an act of terrorism,” Victoria state police Commissioner Graham Ashton said on Tuesday. “We believe this person was there with those sorts of [terrorist] intentions, albeit we don’t know whether it was something planned or something spontaneous at this stage,” he said. Victoria police shot dead the man involved in the hostage situation at an a...

item.title: Aussie Police Foil Christmas Attack - The Daily Beast
item.description:
Aussie Police Foil Christmas Attack  The Daily Beast

Five men were arrested in Australia on Friday on suspicion of plotting a series of bombings in Melbourne on Christmas, police said. The suspects were identified only as men between the ages of 21 and 26, with four of them born in Australia and the fifth in Egypt. Victoria state Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said the men were inspired by the Islamic State and were planning attacks on the city’s Flinders Street train station, neighboring Federation Square and St. Paul’s Cathedral, CBS News reported. The men were believed to be planning a series of attacks using explosives, knives an...

item.title: ‘You’re weak and you should resign’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘You’re weak and you should resign’  The Australian

KEY DEVELOPMENTS • Attacker named as Yacqub Khayre, 29, from Roxburgh Park • Khayre was on parole at the time of the incident • Victoria Police are treating it as a terrorist incident • Islamic State has claimed responsibility • An employee of the apartments, a Chinese-born Australian man, was shot dead 2.20pm: GPS tamper sparked alert Long-time criminal Yacqub Khayre tampered with his GPS ankle bracelet during a terror attack that killed an innocent man and wounded three police officers, AAP reports. Police are investigating whether Khayre deliberately lured them into a deadly ambush after...

item.title: Hostage-taker in Australia had been acquitted of plotting terror attack on Sydney army base - The Telegraph
item.description:
Hostage-taker in Australia had been acquitted of plotting terror attack on Sydney army base  The Telegraph

A gunman who killed a man and took a woman hostage before dying in a police shootout had been acquitted of plotting a terror attack at a Sydney army base years earlier, police said on Tuesday. Three police officers were wounded. The siege on Monday at an apartment building in a Melbourne suburb was being treated as an act of terror, but Victoria state Police Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton said the gunman appeared to have acted alone and not as part of any ongoing plot or threat. "There is nothing that we've found thus far that would suggest to us that this was anything that was ... planne...

item.title: Fairness fears if Pell charged - The Australian
item.description:
Fairness fears if Pell charged  The Australian

Victoria Police Commissioner Graham Ashton yesterday said a decision would be made quickly. However, the assurance of a deadline is understood to have been met with scepticism by church officials, given the matter has gone back and forth between police and prosecutors for more than a year. Combined with the long-running Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse, which has probed allegations of child sex abuse by some Catholic priests and others, claims against Cardinal Pell that date back about 40 years have been the subject of extensive media attention and public ...

item.title: 3 Men Charged Over Alleged 'Mass Killing' Terror Plot in Australia - VOA News
item.description:
3 Men Charged Over Alleged 'Mass Killing' Terror Plot in Australia  VOA News

Three men have been arrested on suspicion of plotting a “mass killing” terror attack in Australia’s second biggest city, Melbourne. Investigators believe the men, aged between 21 and 30, had been inspired by the group calling itself Islamic State. The suspects are Australian nationals of Turkish descent and had been under surveillance since March. Police say the trio recently had their passports cancelled over fears they would travel overseas to engage in terrorism activities.Two of the men are brothers and all three have been charged with terrorist offenses. Authorities assert that they ha...

item.title: 'It could have been a different outcome': Police chief's 'trolley man' warning - ABC News
item.description:
'It could have been a different outcome': Police chief's 'trolley man' warning  ABC News

An online fundraiser has raised more than $100,000 for a man who confronted the Bourke Street terrorist with a shopping trolley during Friday's deadly attack. Mr Rogers, who is believed to be homeless, said on the weekend he was "no hero" and was simply trying to help. He told today's The Age newspaper he had served a five-year jail term for aggravated burglary in the past and had a long history of drug use. He said the decision to intervene was made on the "spur of the moment," the newspaper reported. The GoFundMe page was set up by Melbourne woman Donna Zen, who described Mr Rogers as an ...

item.title: Bourke Street attack 'trolley man' says 'I'm no hero' - ABC News
item.description:
Bourke Street attack 'trolley man' says 'I'm no hero'  ABC News

The man who tried to bring down an Islamic State-inspired terrorist with nothing more than a shopping trolley says he is "no hero". "I got him. I didn't quite get him down," says Michael "trolley man" Rogers Dubbed "trolley man" for his efforts, Michael Rogers has become a cult figure in the city in the past 36 hours. The acclaim comes after he was seen on video of Friday's Bourke Street terrorist attack using a shopping trolley to try to prevent Hassan Khalif Shire Ali from continuing his deadly rampage. Shire Ali died in hospital after being shot by a rookie police constable who was just ...

item.title: Police hunting ‘trolley man’ hero - The Advertiser
item.description:
Police hunting ‘trolley man’ hero  The Advertiser

Victoria Police are searching for Michael Rogers, 46, in relation to a number of alleged burglaries in the Melbourne CBD and St Kilda areas. The homeless man attracted international media attention after he was captured on video shoving a shopping trolley at a knife-wielding attacker in the city last Friday. Rogers can be seen hurtling a metal trolley towards Hassan Khalif Shire Ali twice, as police worked to apprehend the attacker before eventually shooting him. His heroic act was seized upon immediately, leading to the moniker ‘Trolley Man’ and praise from the public. Ali had crashed his ...

item.title: Gas-laden truck set afire, three stabbed, one dead in Australia terror attack - Reuters
item.description:
Gas-laden truck set afire, three stabbed, one dead in Australia terror attack  Reuters

A Somali-born man set fire to a pickup truck laden with gas cylinders in the center of the Australian city of Melbourne on Friday and stabbed three people, killing one, before he was shot by police in a rampage they called an act of terrorism. Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, without providing any evidence. The utility truck carrying barbecue gas cylinders burned on busy Bourke Street just before the evening rush hour as the driver stabbed bystanders and attacked police. (For map click here: tmsnrt.rs/2Qu5stX) The cylinders did not explode and the fire was put out in 10 ...

item.title: Melbourne stabber drove car loaded with gas cylinders: police - Reuters
item.description:
Melbourne stabber drove car loaded with gas cylinders: police  Reuters

Australian police on Friday said a Somali man who stabbed three people in the city of Melbourne on Friday drove a car laden with gas cylinders which caught fire and that they are treating the attack as terrorism. The man stabbed three people, killing one, before he was shot by police. He later died in hospital, Victoria Police Commissioner Graham Ashton told reporters. "We don't believe there is an ongoing threat at this stage, but certainly we are treating it as a terrorism incident," Ashton said. He declined to identify the attacker, but said he was Somali with "family associations that a...

item.title: Australia police: Melbourne attacker also planned explosion - The Associated Press
item.description:
Australia police: Melbourne attacker also planned explosion  The Associated Press

SYDNEY (AP) — Australia police said Saturday a man who fatally stabbed another and injured two in what they described as an Islamic State-inspired terrorist attack in central Melbourne had also planned to set off an explosion. The attacker, Hassain Khalif Shire Ali, 30, had his passport canceled in 2015 after it was learned he planned to travel to Syria, police said. The attack occurred on Friday when Shire Ali got out of a pickup vehicle, which he then set on fire, and stabbed three men, one of whom died at the scene. The attack horrified hundreds of onlookers during the afternoon rush hou...

item.title: Australian police say stabbing attack linked to terrorism - The Associated Press
item.description:
Australian police say stabbing attack linked to terrorism  The Associated Press

SYDNEY (AP) — A knife-wielding man stabbed three people, one fatally, in Australia's second-largest city on Friday in an attack police linked to terrorism. The attack during the afternoon rush hour brought central Melbourne to a standstill. Hundreds of people watched from behind barricades as police tried to apprehend the attacker. Police said the man got out of a pickup truck, which then caught fire, and attacked three bystanders with a knife. He also attempted to attack police who arrived on the scene before being shot in the chest by an officer. The suspect died later at a hospital. One ...

item.title: Melbourne attack: $80K raised for 'trolley man,' hero of Bourke Street stabbing - CNN
item.description:
Melbourne attack: $80K raised for 'trolley man,' hero of Bourke Street stabbing  CNN

A homeless man who intervened in a terror attack in the Australian city of Melbourne Friday has been hailed a hero, with over $80,000 (AUD 116,000) donated to a fund to thank him. Shaky cellphone images from the scene showed a man repeatedly shoving a shopping cart, known as a shopping trolley in Australia, at attacker Hassan Khalif Shire Ali who had just stabbed three people and was threatening police officers with a knife. Social media soon lit up with talk of the brave bystander who had tried to thwart the attack which unfolded within minutes during rush hour on a busy street in the city...

item.title: 'Life goes on': Thousands mark WW1 Armistice in Australia, unbowed by attack - Reuters
item.description:
'Life goes on': Thousands mark WW1 Armistice in Australia, unbowed by attack  Reuters

Thousands of people attended memorial services across Melbourne to mark the centenary of the Armistice ending World War One, shrugging off heightened security after Friday's attack in Australia's second largest city which police branded terrorism. Attendance at Melbourne's the Shrine of Remembrance was bigger than expected, with visitors determined to show they were not bowed by Friday's stabbing of three civilians, one fatal, by Islamic State sympathizer Hassan Khalif Shire Ali, 30. "Carry on," Kate Mansell, the mother of a toddler and a baby in a stroller, told Reuters. "Life goes on," sa...

item.title: The Latest: IS claims responsibility for Australia attack - The Associated Press
item.description:
The Latest: IS claims responsibility for Australia attack  The Associated Press

SYDNEY (AP) — The Latest on a knife attack in Melbourne (all times local): 10:45 p.m. The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for an attack in Australia that police say was linked to terrorism. Police say the driver of a pickup truck got out of his vehicle, which then caught fire, and attacked three bystanders with a knife before being fatally shot by police on Friday in Melbourne, Australia's second-largest city. Police said the attacker came from Somalia. The militant group said in a statement released through its Aamaq media arm that the man was "one of Islamic State fighters"...

item.title: Melbourne attacker had passport cancelled in 2015 because he wanted to fight for Isis - The Guardian
item.description:
Melbourne attacker had passport cancelled in 2015 because he wanted to fight for Isis  The Guardian

The man who was killed after stabbing a passerby to death and injuring two others in Melbourne had his passport cancelled in 2015 because he wanted to fight for Islamic State in Syria. But despite being known to the police and intelligence agencies, Hassan Khalif Shire Ali, 30, was not being actively monitored before Friday afternoon’s Bourke Street attack. Shire Ali, drove a 4x4 vehicle loaded with gas bottles into the city centre, ignited the vehicle into a ball of flames and then attacked passers-by with a knife. Police shot him at the scene and he died in hospital on Friday night. The d...

item.title: Australia police say Melbourne attacker was known to authorities - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Australia police say Melbourne attacker was known to authorities  Al Jazeera English

Australian police said on Saturday a man who fatally stabbed a person and injured two others in central Melbourne "held radicalised views" that prompted him to carry out the attack. The perpetrator, Hassain Khalif Shire Ali, 30, had his passport canceled in 2015 after it was learned he planned to travel to Syria, police said. The attack occurred on Friday when Shire Ali got out of a pickup vehicle, which he then set on fire, and stabbed three men, one of whom died at the scene. The attack on Bourke Street horrified hundreds of onlookers during the afternoon rush hour in Australia's second-b...

item.title: Melbourne police see Islamic State 'inspiration' behind stabbings - Reuters
item.description:
Melbourne police see Islamic State 'inspiration' behind stabbings  Reuters

An Australian man who set fire to a truck laden with gas cylinders in the center of Melbourne and stabbed one person to death was inspired by Islamic State but did not have direct links with the group, police said on Saturday. Police identified the man responsible for Friday's attack as Somali-born Hassan Khalif Shire Ali, 30, and said he was radicalized and inspired by the militant group's propaganda. He was shot by police and died in hospital. Police said Shire Ali's Australian passport was canceled in 2015 after an intelligence report he planned to travel to Syria, but an assessment was ...

item.title: Melbourne attack: police name Hassan Khalif Shire Ali and say he was known to them - The Guardian
item.description:
Melbourne attack: police name Hassan Khalif Shire Ali and say he was known to them  The Guardian

Police are treating an attack at Bourke Street mall in Melbourne in which one person was stabbed to death and two others injured as a terrorist incident. The man, identified as Hassan Khalif Shire Ali, 30, drove a 4x4 truck loaded with gas bottles into the city centre, ignited the vehicle in a ball of flames and then attacked passers-by with a knife. He was shot by police at the scene of the attack and died in hospital on Friday night. Counter-terrorism investigators were raiding two addresses in Werribee and Meadows Heights on Saturday morning, police said. Graham Ashton, the chief commiss...
